scenarioText: There are 30 balls in a box and 6 of them are red.
question: We take out eight balls one at a time from the box with replacement. How many of them are red balls?
feedback: Number of trials is fixed in this situation, and what of interest is number of successes.
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
          It has x-axis 'Number of red balls' with labels 0, 2, 4, 6 and 8.
          It has y-axis 'Prob. of a specific number of red balls' with labels 0.0, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3.
          The chart is a bar chart with 6 vertical bars.
          Bar 1 is centered at 0, and length is from 0 to 0.17.
          Bar 2 is centered at 1, and length is from 0 to 0.34.
          Bar 3 is centered at 2, and length is from 0 to 0.29.
          Bar 4 is centered at 3, and length is from 0 to 0.15.
          Bar 5 is centered at 4, and length is from 0 to 0.05.
          Bar 6 is centered at 5, and length is from 0 to 0.01.
ylab: Prob. of a specific number of red balls

scenarioText: There are 30 balls in a box and 6 of them are red.
question: We take balls out of the box one at a time with replacement. How many times are needed until we get three red balls?
feedback: In this situation, number of successes is fixed and what we want to know is the number of trials.
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
          It has x-axis 'Number of balls drawn out before we get three red balls' with labels 0, 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50.
          It has y-axis 'Prob. of seeing three red balls in a specific trial number' with labels 0.000, 0.025, 0.050, 0.075 and 0.100.
          The chart is a bar chart with 56 vertical bars.
          From 0 to 10, there is a steep increase to about 0.060 in probability (started near zero), then it gradually trails off until probability approaches 0 around 50.
xlab: Number of balls drawn out before we get three red balls
ylab: Prob. of seeing three red balls in a specific number of trials

scenarioText: There are 30 balls in a box and 6 of them are red.
question: We take balls out of the box one at a time with replacement. How many times are needed until the first red ball is taken out?
feedback: What we want to know is the number of trials until we see the first success.
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
          It has x-axis 'Number of balls drawn out before we get the first red ball' with labels 0, 10, 20 and 30.
          It has y-axis 'Prob. of seeing the first red ball in a specific trial number' with labels 0.00, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.20 and 0.25.
          The chart is a bar chart with 34 vertical bars.
          The probability starts at 0.2 at 0 with a steep decrease until it approaches probability 0 around 25.
xlab: Number of balls drawn out before we get the first red ball
ylab: Prob. of seeing the first red ball in a specific trial number

scenarioText: There are 30 balls in a box and 6 of them are red.
question: We draw one ball out of the box. What is the probability of taking out a red ball?
feedback: Because the trial number is only one,
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
          It has x-axis 'Number of times drawn out' with labels 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1.00.
          It has y-axis 'Prob. of getting a red ball in one trial' with labels 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 and 0.8.
          The chart is a set of 1 line.
          Line 1 connects 2 points, at (0, 0.8) and (1, 0.2).
ylab: Prob. of getting a red ball in one trial

scenarioText: There are 30 balls in a box and 6 of them are red.
question: We take out eight balls from the box without replacement. How many of them are red balls?
feedback: Number of trials is fixed and the probability of success changes (without replacement) .
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
          It has x-axis 'Number of red balls drawn' with labels 0, 2, 4 and 6.
          It has y-axis 'Prob. of getting specific amount of red balls out of eight draws' with labels 0.0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4.
          The chart is a bar chart with 5 vertical bars.
          Bar 1 is centered at 0, and length is from 0 to 0.13.
          Bar 2 is centered at 1, and length is from 0 to 0.35.
          Bar 3 is centered at 2, and length is from 0 to 0.34.
          Bar 4 is centered at 3, and length is from 0 to 0.15.
          Bar 5 is centered at 4, and length is from 0 to 0.03.
ylab: Prob. of getting specific amount of red balls out of eight draws

scenarioText: In Pennsylvania, 10% of vehicles order a Big Mac in the drive thru window of McDonalds.
question: What is the probability that 5 of next 7 cars order a Big Mac?
feedback: Because the trial number is only one,
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
            It has x-axis 'Number of cars that order a Big Mac' with labels 0, 2, 4, 6 and 8.
            It has y-axis 'Prob. of that amount of vehicles ordering a Big Mac in 7 cars' with labels 0.0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5.
            The chart is a bar chart with 4 vertical bars.
            Bar 1 is centered at 0, and length is from 0 to 0.48.
            Bar 2 is centered at 1, and length is from 0 to 0.37.
            Bar 3 is centered at 2, and length is from 0 to 0.12.
            Bar 4 is centered at 3, and length is from 0 to 0.02.
xlab: Number of cars that order a Big Mac
ylab: Prob. of that amount of vehicles ordering a Big Mac in 7 cars

scenarioText: 40% of the people in a college town have type A blood. There is a Red Cross Station where people from the town donate blood.
question: What is the probability that a donor has type A blood?
feedback: Because the trial number is only one,
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
            It has x-axis 'Number of donors' with labels 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1.00.
            It has y-axis 'Prob. of a donor having type A blood' with labels 0.40, 0.45, 0.50, 0.55, 0.60 and 0.65.
            The chart is a set of 1 line.
            Line 1 connects 2 points, at (0, 0.6) and (1, 0.4).
ylab: Prob. of a donor having type A blood

scenarioText: 40% of the people in a college town have type A blood. There is a Red Cross Station where people from the town donate blood.
question: How many people went to this blood donation station until the first type A blood donor appears?
feedback: What we want to know is the number of trials until we see the first success.

This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
            It has x-axis 'Number of donors' with labels 0, 5, 10 and 15.
            It has y-axis 'Prob. of the first type A blood donor going to the station' with labels 0.0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4.
            The chart is a bar chart with 12 vertical bars.
            It starts at probability 0.4 at 0 with a steep decrease down to 0 probability until 10.

scenarioText: 40% of the people in a college town have type A blood. There is a Red Cross Station where people from the town donate blood.
question: One day, 10 donators went to this blood donation station. What is the probability that 6 among these 10 people have type A blood?
feedback: Number of trials is fixed in this situation, and what of interest is number of successes.
aria:
This chart has title 'PMF Graph'.
            It has x-axis 'Number of type A blood donors' with labels 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10.
            It has y-axis 'Prob. of a specific number of type A blood donors in 10 donors' with labels 0.0, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3.
            The chart is a bar chart with 11 vertical bars.
            There is a bell curve shape from 0 to 9 and the probability reaches 0.25 at the peak, which is at 4.
xlab: Number of type A blood donors
ylab: Prob. of a specific number of type A blood donors in 10 donors

scenarioText: 40% of the people in a college town have type A blood. There is a Red Cross Station where people from the town donate blood.
